Anti-Aliasing Optimization for Mask Images

Overview

This project focuses on optimizing 3D printing resolution by applying Anti-Aliasing (AA) and Gaussian blurring to binary mask images. By improving edge transitions in mask patterns, the fidelity and smoothness of 3D-printed surfaces can be significantly enhanced.

Project Description

The study aims to improve the accuracy and resolution of 3D-printed components by enhancing the quality of binary mask images used in the printing process. Typically, the use of low-resolution masks leads to aliasing effects, causing jagged edges and inaccuracies in printed models. This project addresses the issue through anti-aliasing techniques including Gaussian blurring and pixel-level edge smoothing.

We used a kernel-based Gaussian smoothing approach to transition sharp binary edges into gradual grayscale gradients, which can be interpreted more accurately by high-resolution printers. The effect of various kernel sizes on resolution and edge preservation was studied using computational tools like MATLAB and Python. Experimental validation was done using test patterns and quality assessment through scanning electron microscopy.

Additionally, an outlook was provided on how Machine Learning (ML) models can further automate AA parameter selection based on input complexity. The outcome of this research contributes toward higher fidelity in additive manufacturing and micro-fabrication processes, especially in biomedical and MEMS domains.
